user_review: Went here pre-covid with my bf and best friend as well as her husband and enjoyed some delicious smoked meat, pickles and french fries. The place is a little small and can get crowded so if you want to check this place out I would go at an odd time or you may need to wait in line. Or if you don't want to dine in, you can get it to go. They had different options of smoked meat if you want it more fatty or lean. The fries were great and you could get a pickle which pairs well with the fried/fatty food. The only thing is this place only takes cash which is a bit of a downside, as you'll need to make sure you have cash handy! All in all if you're visiting Montreal or just looking for some good smoked meat, this is a go to!
*home delivery review* Amazing. Literally tastes exactly like what you get at the restaurant, minus the long lines!! Price is very fair, and the quality of the food is unbeatable. So. Worth. It.

I must add a disclaimer to this review since I've been eating at Schwartz's for over 50 years. There have been times while eating there, my medium-lean sandwich was not up to snuff (and I've never ever had an issue getting it replaced) but the medium-lean sandwiches we had on July 31 were melt in your mouth tender and it was the Schwartz's that I remember since I was a kid. It was 6:30 pm walked into a nearly deserted restaurant that we've never seen so dead. Every other table was removed for social distancing. Everyone was wearing masks. Plexiglass all along the counters. As soon as customers got up, the table and chairs were all disinfected. The food quickly came out hot and fresh. Both sandwiches were excellent, fries were decent and pickle was perfectly sour. No condiments on the tables, waiter brought them to you. AFAIC, other than modifications to the restaurant layout due to Covid-19, the only difference from 7/31/2020 compared to my childhood memories is a tenfold increase in price -- and now poutine is on the menu ‍

One of my favorite Quebecois institutions!No trip to Montreal is ever complete without a stop at Schwartz's for a smoked meat sandwich the size of my head -- and the portions are HUGE!I lean toward the fatty cuts -- so tasty and  filling! (P.S.: You can choose fatty over lean, or vice versa -- your call.)

Is there anything better that a true Smoked meat sandwich?  This place is a Montreal staple and one that everyone should try.   mmmm. Only issue is the line ups to get in.   Definitely get there early and be prepared to wait in line to get in. Food was extremely satisfying and portions were decent.   Will be back but best to come in off peak hours.

This place opens late hours and so close to Montreal University. The night life here is so fun with a lot of restaurants and bars open. This is the first place I visited after arriving to Montreal (as I was really hungry then! ) This is one of the signature dishes of Canada that you must try. I ordered 3 sandwiches with different meats and all of them are good.

Came here to of course try the smoke meat sandwich. Also shared poutine with a friend. I suggest you just skip the fries TBH. They were not that great. However, the sandwich was delicious. The meat was so juicy and tender. They keep their sandwiches pretty simple, all you're getting is meat, bread and some mustard, usually not my style but that's all this needed.You may have to wait a while to be seated. When I got there, there were 5 to 6 parties ahead of me and it took about 15 minutes to get seated so that's not bad. So I guess if there's more than 10 parties, you might be waiting a while. The block that this restaurant is located on has other places to try out if that's the case
You know it's just your classic smoked meat sandwich place. It's a must go to ! Definitely get the pickles

Had Schwartz for take out the other day and we ordered the smoked meat sandwich. We actually ordered from two delis to compare the different smoked meat sandwiches from Schwartz's competitors, and it was a tie. Schwartz's sandwich is quite tasty, and the meat itself was a bit fatty, which added to the juiciness and tenderness of the sandwich. Schwartz's pickle was delicious and very satisfying! Would recommend, especially given that it's a Montreal staple.

Skip the main line and order to-go! The line moves much faster and there's actually some tables in the back where you can quickly scarf down your sandwich and mosey on out. Though there was a line for the lunch rush even in the to-go section, we were in and out in less than 30 mins.We ordered two smoked meat sandwiches, one medium fat, one medium lean, and honestly they looked at tasted like two different sandwiches. Lean is chewier and less oily, as the name implies, the fat is more tender. The mustard was tasty and the servings of meat were generous. The cherry soda is VERY sweet. Pairs well with the sandwich but be careful if you're not a fan of super sugary drinks.

I have been to Montreal many times and while I had heard so many great things about Schwartz's, I was never that interested in checking it out and the restaurant was never on my priority list. It wasn't until last month when I finally made the trip to New York's pastrami institution Katz's Deli for the first time since moving to NYC almost ten years ago that I finally convinced myself to visit Schwartz's on my next trip to Montreal. Compared to the experience at Katz's you'll find the experience at Schwartz's to be much more laid back. Although my friend who is a Montreal local had warned me about the long lines and the grimy counters at Schwartz's, it was nothing compared to the queue or the griminess at Katz's. In fact, I was pleasantly surprised to see that there was no line when I got there around 1pm on a weekday and was immediately seated at the counter by a friendly staff member. I was also happy to see that the counters and tables had been wiped down before being seated because that's definitely not the experience that you get at Katz's since they are always super busy. My smoked meat sandwich was ready within a matter of minutes after being seated. As with Katz's the sandwich looked massive with clumps of meat sticking out, but the meat is very tender so it's not as heavy as it looks and the sandwich is quite manageable even for one person. As soon as I took a bite out of it I wondered why it had taken me so long to make it out to Schwartz's. It was the same feeling that went through my head when I first took a bite out of my pastrami sandwich at Katz's. As of February 2020, Schwartz's is cash only although they do take Canadian debit cards and US dollars. If you're paying in US dollars you will be charged 20% more than if you were to pay in Canadian dollars, but considering that the smoked meat sandwich here is less than half  the price of the pastrami or reuben sandwiches at Katz's, paying that extra 20% will still make the sandwich at Schwartz's pretty affordable. If you want to pay in Canadian dollars, but don't have any cash on you, there is an ATM  machine at the back of the store although the ATM will charge fee of 1.50 Canadian dollars. Just as Katz's is a New York institution that everyone should visit at least once, Schwartz's is also an institution that every meat lover should try in Montreal.

It's the place on the must go list for tourists in Montreal and there are often long lines in winter and summer. In my personal opinion, it's an okay place for a smoked meat sandwich. It's worth trying if you are in the area and if you want to avoid lines, I would recommend to go either around 5-6 on a Monday or Tuesday night, it seems to be less crowded to me.

Five stars. This place lived up to the hype, at least for us it did. The smoked meat was terrific and service by our server, Bahram, was outstanding. Prices were reasonable. We enjoyed the entire experience.Schwartz's Montreal Hebrew Delicatessen is a famous deli in Montreal. It's an institution; the oldest deli in Canada, opened in 1928. It's perhaps the most popular place to eat at in the city. It's old school, cash only, and reminds me of Katz's Delicatessen in Manhattan. Like Katz's, Schwartz's is a Jewish kosher-style deli. Unlike Katz's, Schwartz's is known for their Montreal-style smoked meat, not pastrami. They're both good, but I like Schwartz's better, not only in terms of food, but in terms of service and atmosphere too. The people are nicer here.From what I've heard and seen, there's usually a line out the door for this place. It's not very big and this is the only location. I guesstimate the restaurant can seat maybe 90-100 customers tops between the dining room tables and the bar. They pack people in. The seating is communal, so if there's just two or three or four of you, you'll most likely be seated together with strangers. Prepare to get cozy.Our group of seven was lucky. We showed up to Schwartz's on a Friday at 11:21am and were seated immediately at an eight-top. It was busy. Almost every seat was taken. When we left, shortly after 12pm, there was a line down the sidewalk to get in. We came at the right time that day.The wall menu above the bar is presented in both French and English and there are helpful pictures too. People come here for the smoked meat, but Schwartz's also sells chicken, liver, turkey, and salami too. The prices are affordable. The total bill for our group of seven guys, after taxes, was only $115.20 Canadian (or $16.46 per person Canadian). And we had leftovers.Here's what we got (all dollars Canadian):* 3 Grande Assiete - large plates of smoked meat ($17.95 each)* 2 Frite - fries ($7.10 each)* 1 Poutine ($6.50)* 2 Salade de Choux - coleslaw ($3.40 each)* 2 Cornichon - French pickles ($2.35 each)* 3 Cerise Noire - Cott black cherry soda ($2.95 each)* 4 Liqueur - soft drinks like Diet Coke ($2.60 each)* 1 Fraise Partage ($2)The smoked meat was amazing. It's smoked beef brisket. Bahram told us Schwartz's smoked meat is cured and marinated for 10 days and then smoked for 8 hours. According to the menu, the meat is prepared with Schwartz's "secret blend of herbs and spices" and smoked daily. You can request slices of meat from lean to fat. We ordered our meat at medium-fat content. I think that's definitely the way to go because our meat was delectable in both taste and texture.Each slice was tender, rich, and flavorful. Plates of sliced rye bread accompanied the meats so we made our own sandwiches. If you don't want to commit to a plate of meat, you can order a single smoked meat sandwich for $10.45. I prepared my smoked meat sandwich with coleslaw and mustard with pickles on the side. It was incredibly delicious. It made me happy. The pickles are served whole and are thick and tart. We cut them up into slices to share.The fries and poutine were tasty. While Schwartz's poutine wasn't as "smothered" as other poutines we had in Montreal were (particularly those in Old Montreal), it was still quite good and I recommend ordering it. Schwartz's version is simple and traditional -- fries, cheese curds, brown gravy; that's it, none of that extra stuff. It may have been my favorite poutine on our trip actually. The fries were hot, golden brown, and crispy; medium thickness.If you come to Schwartz's, you have to have your smoked meat sandwich with a Cerise Noire or Cott black cherry soda to drink. It's a tradition. In 2018, the Canadian Broadcasting Corporation reported about 50% of Schwartz's customers drink a Cott black cherry soda with their smoked meat sandwich: cbc.ca/news/canada/montr…. Schwartz's gives you a glass of ice with your can of soda.Bahram was a delight. We were fortunate to have him as our server. He was very friendly and pleasant. Not only did he describe Schwartz's food to us, but he also pointed out various celebrity customers in the pictures on the wall (after I asked him about a photo of him with Seth Rogen). Many celebrities have come to eat here and most are shown off on the wall which is just filled with photographs, autographs, and newspaper and magazine clippings. I sat next to one of my friends who sat exactly where Chris Rock sat when Chris Rock ate here.You can pay at the table or at the register. As mentioned above, this place is cash only. If you don't have cash and don't want to use the restaurant's ATM, there are banks within two blocks on St Laurent.There are two small restrooms inside, one for men and one for ladies.Schwartz's should be on any Montreal visitor's to-do list. Even our pescatarian friend joined us and had a good time.

If you have ever been to Katz Delicatessen in NYC this place is comparable to it! My friends and I decided to give this place a try and got the smoked meat sandwich to share. The meat was both lean and fatty. Our biggest mistake was not doing our research and realizing that there was a take out spot for Schwartz's right next door AFTER our meal...The tables in this establishment are incredibly close to one another. It made it really hard for people to get in and out and there was no flow of traffic for customers trying to get in and out. This cramped environment made it hard for someone who's claustrophobic to truly enjoy the full experience.

Giant pickle: DAMN!!!Smoked meat, mustard. It's not ham.The fries too? They slam.Schwartz's has some serious hype behind it. Like every "amazing" restaurant, I'm always hesitant that the fame will have gotten itself entrenched into the food so deeply that any remnants of reality will be lost. Schwartz's is as real as food gets. It's unapologetically itself: the fries are so greasy, the smoked meat is piled too high to properly eat, and the cherry cola has way too many sugar cubes dissolved inside to be considered legal by many foodie standards. The servers are people, with personalities and quips, and will give you any attitude you give them right back. And you know what? Schwartz's provides the best meal in Montreal. We can't wait to come back.

Atmosphere/Service: This place was so packed and busy when we went. There was a line through the door leading outside. I remember the last time I was here, the same thing happened so I wasn't surprised. But luckily the line went fast, and if you go with a party of two or less the wait time isn't that bad. It's when you go with a party of 4 or more when it's harder to grab a seat. The servers were also super nice but a bit pushy as the turnover time here is usually 20 mins or so.Menu/food: Most people who come here know that ordering the smoked meat is where it's at. Everything else is outsourced, and the only thing made in store is the smoked meat. You can get the sandwich made ready to eat, or platter wise where you'd make your own sandwiches, and easier to share. Food was so good. The meat were all lean and as salty and savoury as can be. i'm not usually a pickle person, but their dill pickle is a definite must!Overall: love the place! Recommend it for a fast eat in Montreal. even if you don't have time, just go next door where their take out options are!

I always love coming back to this place for smoked meat sandwiches. Service was fast and we got our order pretty quick. I wish that our meat was hotter. It seemed pretty cold when we were served it. We ordered a lean meat sandwich each. They charge $2 if guests share dishes instead of ordering their own. They only accept debit and cash. Place is pretty small and not recommended to bring in a lot of personal belongings.

Walked in. Sat down. Told the guy to bring me whatever is most popular. He winked at me and 2 mins later gave me a lean-semi fat sandwich and became my new best friend. I bought two 4 gallon pepper jars when I left. Get the peppers. I love this place.

So had some Schwartz's last week. Take-out and not sit in. Good, very good even, but not the same.Looking forward to when I am comfortable to sit down and chomp in. Until then the takeout will have to do.See you in September Schwartz!

Yes, yes, and YES! If you're in Montreal, you've got to go to Schwartz for their famous Montreal smoked meat sandwich. For those who don't know, Montreal is famous for their smoked meat. It is made using beef brisket cured with spices and seasoning for about a week to allow for flavor absorption. The meat is then smoked, steamed, and packed between two slices of light rye bread with mustard slathered on. In addition, with smoked meat, there's different levels of fattiness you can choose from. The sandwich may look small at first, but they really pack it. The smoked meat was so tender, moist, fatty, flavorful with a slight smokiness to it. It was honestly one of the best things I ate on the trip. If you're looking for local flavor, this is the place to be. I recommend calling ahead of time for takeout, because from what I've heard and seen, there's always a line out of the door.

Fantastic sandwiches served here!!! Believe the hype but don't wait in the long line, unless you really want to. The smoked meat sandwich is so tender and packed with flavor! It comes on rye bread and slathered with mustard, if I'm being honest, items I don't particularly care for, but IT WORKS! Oh man, the bread complimented the meat and the mustard blends in so well. I couldn't believe how good it was! Makes my mouth water as we speak!Like I said, don't wait in the long line, go to the deli counter and take the sandwich to go, no waiting! The people behind the counter have that sandwich whipped up in no time! They have some stools and a counter in the back, where you can eat, or you can go across the street and eat in the cute painted storage container. They offer various souvenirs, of which I took home some seasoning and also take credit cards.Worth the hype and your time!! Check it out!

Tried the smoke meat sandwich, platter and French fries which were all okay. No complaints, but not something I'd make a special trip for again. The place seems to attract quite a few tourists (myself one of them) given it's a long time establishment. Only complaint I had was about the rudeness of the man at the register. I get it, you're dealing with tourists all day long, but isn't it human decency to be pleasant to one another?Be warned, they accept Canadian cash only ! There is an atm machine in the back of the restaurant though.

The one thing that everyone could agree on when it came to things to do in Montreal was to stop at Schwartz and order a smoked meat sandwich. So that is exactly what we did!We came around 3:00 and there was essentially no line up although we saw a food group finishing up so we must of just missed the rush we thought! We were seated right away and the server was incredibly friendly. We received our food within minutes! We both ordered a smoked Montreal "medium" meat sandwich. Let me tell you, once I took a bite into this amazingness that is a sandwich, I was hooked! I ate it up so fast and I did add slightly more mustard. Now, it is recommended that you complete the experience with a cherry cola but I just can't stand cherry cola but my husband ordered it. He did make a comment it does taste great with it.A must stop for sure!

Retro feel, simple and amazingly delicious. Get: smoked meat sandwich (medium -- some lean, some fatty), plate of fries (crispy outside, soft flavorful inside), a pickle (perhaps share one between two ppl), and black cherry coke.Add extra mustard to your sandwich as you eat it. Fall in love.
absolute must go - Hands down best smoked meat ever. Poutine is also fire, and regular fries. Jamal is goat waiter. Super fast service , greet vibe , OG place. Must go when in MTL

We visited Schwartz's around 2PM in the afternoon, and the lineup wasn't that bad at all! Maybe 20 minutes?The inside is a bit cramped and a hole in the wall, which is to be expected since it's such a long-term establishment.Each of us ordered a smoked meat sandwich (of course!) and my Montreal friend said that the pickles were a must. We also shared a plate of fries. This ended up being way too much food for us - we could've went without the fries or the pickles, especially considering that they were only 'aite. But that's not what we came for anyway!The smoked meat sandwich came with a heaping mountain of smoke beef brisket. And oh my, it was an amazing mountain of meat. It was tender, flavourful, juicy.. and I ate it all, despite it being way too much food.Considering the quality of the sandwich I got, I was quite happy. A great way to end a trip to Montreal!

Amazing smoked meat with big portion. This is in fact the only place to try for Montreal smoked meat. Look no further as you won't be disappointed. We ordered smoked meat poutine and 4 sandwiches. The poutine was tasty but when we moved to the sandwich, it quite too much for us.

We just happened to walk by this place and a bystander told us it was a must. To be honest, I didn't need to be sold as you could see smoked meats through the windowThis place is supposed to be the #1 deli in North America and I believe it. The smoked meat sandwhich was incredible. Not too fatty but still had tons of flavor and melted in your mouth. Fries were good and the service rocked!

As a former New Yorker who practically grew in in Deli's -- I was anxious to try the famous Montreal Smoked Meat sandwich and I have to say it was a big letdown. If you've been to Katz's in NYC or Langers in Los Angeles you'll know what I mean. More like a Pastrami sandwich then brisket, we ordered one lean and one medium fatty (but when they came I saw no difference). It wasn't horrible but nothing to make a special trip for. The price was a lot lower than in New York - I'll give them that. The g/f tried the turkey sandwich which was made withheap, processed turkey -- a crime to be served at a famous deli. French Fries were on the greasy side. I literally have nothing to recommend here -- even the service wasn't good and our server was rude (maybe he used to work in New York? )Check the hours before you come as Yelp stated they opened at 9am on Sundays -- we went recently and they open at 10am. Not sure about other days. I've alerted Yelp to the mistake -- hope they change the hours as we waited 45 minutes for them to open (another mistake).

Great prices & great sandwiches. As a NJ/NY native, this place definitely lived up to the expectations of having delicious smoked meat sandwiches, and the interior is super humble. The walls are lined with different posters and magazine covers, as well as little models of Schwartz's itself. I also like the layout of multiple long tables, since you can just sit and chill alongside other tourists and natives enjoying themselves.The only thing that hurt my experience was the service. Upon entering, our waiter was pretty curt, which was understandable because it's such a busy place. But when I wanted to ask my waiter what people usually got, he got frustrated with me and didn't answer my question! I was taken aback, since I didn't think it'd be that uncommon of an inquiry. Anyways, I'm definitely willing to come back, but maybe I'll just grab my sammy to go next time.

Is it a touristy spot? Yes. Are the lines long? Yes. Was the sandwich everything I didn't know I needed? YES. We visited Montreal for the first time over the weekend, and as someone from Philly who understands sandwich hype, particular when it comes to meat, (here's looking at you Philly cheesesteaks and Katz's Deli in NYC), I was expecting this to be an over-hyped institution. I'm generally not a fan of salty foods and lean meat, so I was wondering if this was going to be comparable to a pastrami. The line was long, and our time was limited. Thankfully, next door to the restaurant, Schwartz's has a take out option where there was no wait. You can order limited items there and seat yourself in the back. We ordered one sandwich to split, and we ordered two pounds of hot smoked meat to go. The meat was melt in your mouth, a bit fatty, not overly seasoned, perfectly paired with some simple rye bread and mustard. It doesn't get any simpler or delectable than this. We regretted splitting a sandwich and contemplated on purchasing one more. This was the most delicious sandwich I've had in such a long time. If you watch any videos/interviews about this place, it really isn't about the bread or any typical fare you would put on a sandwich, the meat is the star.

Don't think I really have to post a review here since there are 2000+ other ones but here it is. We came late so there wasn't a wait.Immediately sat down, ordered our food and it was out within minutes. We ordered three plates of meat and a poutine. Each item we ordered individually and they came out within a minute.Our server was incredibly attentive, gave us the history on the restaurant and the famous people that come in. Hallie Berry tried to cut the line but they sent her out to wait with everyone else

I have never had smoked meat before and was really excited to try it as the people I was travelling with raved a lot about this place. We opted to take out rather than sit in because the line to sit in was longer and I was sure it would take longer to to get seats for. The line for takeout was not that long so that was good. We got the smoked meat sandwich and it was really really REALLY good! The mustard went so well with the meat and the amount of meat you get is beyond what I expected. You get a mouthful of that tender meat in every single bite and it gives that you satisfaction. We also got some meat in containers to bring it back. I would love to come back here!

As seen on many travel shows is this place. They tell you to come here to try out their legendary "Smoked Meat" sandwich. Well, I did and here's how it went!Atmosphere/Appearance: Set right off of a busy street in what seemed like a college town is this gem. It seems to always be busy in here so if you come in the likelihood of being sat with complete strangers is pretty high. There's nothing wrong with that though. The benches are designed to hold a total of 6 people and there's a decent amount of seating at the bar as well. You can't hang out in here after eating. If you aren't stuffing your face and are just chatting, you'll get asked to leave because a line forms quickly outside. Rude, but I guess that's a part of the aura here. Eat and go. There isn't much decor, just a bunch of memorabilia from celebrities who have visited and stuff.Service: Pretty awesome actually. I forget his name, but he was bald, spoke very good English and knew how to make people laugh. He seemed to be the "face" of the restaurant since he did most of the talking and order-taking. I mean, we got our waters and stuff, but it's not a 5-star restaurant so don't expect to be "waited on".Food: Very, very good. I had their legendary "Smoked Meat Sandwich" and a side of coleslaw. The sandwich was smaller than I expected so you're going to want a side. The food was impressive and I do see all of the hype surrounding Schwartz's.Value: CASH ONLY. I don't like that the restaurant doesn't tell you that until your food is practically in your lap and that was only because I noticed a sign above the cashier's desk. I mean, maybe I wasn't paying attention, but yeah. Of course there's an ATM in the back you can use but they don't take cards at all. CASH ONLY.Pretty decent spot, but I think I'm all set with my 1 visit here. The only reason I'd come back is to pre-order their duck that they literally go out and hunt for you. Lol. You have to put in and pay for an order a few days in advance then they notify you when your duck (that you order by the pound) is ready. So I'm still interested in that, but we shall see.

Regardless of how one feels between the ongoing debate between New York and Montreal Jewish institutions, I feel a trip to Montreal is never complete without a visit to Schwartz's. New Yorkers might be quick to compare this place to Katz's, but given that the process of their dry-cured meats are somewhat different, it's a tough comparison.I always recommend the counter experience, since the guys behind the counter are super friendly. They also have a number of tables, but every time I've come here it's been too crowded to nab one. It's a little on the narrow side and since this place is frequented by tourists and some locals, there is never a slow time. I don't mind waiting personally, the aroma of the meats keeps me happy.The menu here is very simple. Buy the meat by the pound or have it in sandwich form. When going with takeout, I usually buy a couple pounds of their pastrami and eat it (happily) later. When dining in, I'm all about the sandwich and a side of poutine. Some folks would prefer a pickle and coleslaw, but the fries are a better option in my opinion.The brisket here is nice and succulent. For a dry-cured meat, I have to say there is a certain kind of moist and airy bite. I appreciate the mustard in the sandwich, but the pastrami on its own is worth its weight in meat sweats. It also is a great group meal option, as long as everyone is a carnivore.The staff couldn't be nicer. I expected a bit of pushiness my first time here but have received exemplary service each time. On occasion they pack the pastrami so tight in the container that it easily weighs more than the amount I paid for. I fully intend on being back soon!

I don't think I have much to add to the Schwartz's reviews that others haven't already said, but being "not a smoked meat fan" I was pleasantly surprised at how delicious the sandwiches were. Nothing fancy - just smoked meat and mustard - but really hit the spot and satisfies.

1) No frills kind of place. No substitutions, nothing off the menu, so don't even try it. I heard people trying to say "no mustard" or our table even asked for hot water.. both things not on the menu. To the "no mustard" response, waiter says "you could try other things on the menu." To the hot water, waiter says no we don't have that but then when I order the tea it literally is a cup of hot water with a tea bag on the side. 2) Seating is limited, so most likely you'll be seated with some strangers. Our table ended up being Chinese and my dad bonded with the folks at our table as we were finishing. It was packed already at 11:17pm, people waiting. 3) smoked meat is delicious! Straight up, nothing else. Heated warm in case anyone is wondering.4) Payment!! Shit. Didn't realize they don't take credit card or debit card. They only accept Canadian dollar and Canadian debit.  they charge 20% extra for USD

To go option for food hopping is quick here. Separate from the dine in the menu was limited. Ordered the half pound hot smoked meat beef and a couple pickles. The smoked beef was nicely seasoned and smoked. Took off some of the best part of the meat -the fat to ensure that I don't get a clogged heart. If you want to dine in you can guarantee a line to wait so have a friend ready to wait in line while another finds parking. Need to try the chicken next time.

A trip to Montreal just isn't complete without visiting Schwartzs. This old school deli has been serving up Montreal-style smoked meat since 1928 and is a staple in the city. The line was out the door on a Thursday evening and bustling with locals & tourists. When it got to us, we all decided on the medium (mix of lean x fatty) smoked meat sandwich; it came with a mountain of smoked brisket piled high between two slices of rye bread and a bit of mustard. Simple but very well done. The meat was flavorful and tender with a touch of smokiness. The rye bread held up well and balanced the savouriness. The mustard gave a nice zing to the dish. Between Katz in New York and Schwartzs, I think I prefer Schwartzs more. It's also much more reasonably priced. Overall, 4.5 stars.
There's always a line up outside Schwartz's and for a good reason. Their delicious food is worth the wait!

An absolute must try for Montréal visitors! Upon entry, you can feel the history of this restaurant and the outlay is like a 19th century deli. We decided to line up and go for the take-out option and while the line seems long at first, it really moves faster than you'd expect. I'd say we waited about 20 minutes which isn't bad. The sandwich itself was incredible but make sure to check they've put enough mustard in it! They're operating fast and can sometimes forget to load up every sandwich with the same amount. Size-wise the sandwich was smaller than expected so you should order more if you're looking for more than a snack. The smoked meat was tender, delicious and very flavourful.Overall a must-try for the smoked meat. They only take Cash and Debit only, no credit.
Keeping it real hereThis place reminds me so much of Katz in lower east  side NYC. Very raw vibe and food was pretty bomb. Much cheaper from my experience too. Overall great experience.

What a great find! A fabulous spot with no frills and delicious a sandwiches. We came here based on the great reviews and we were not disappointed! What a great bite on a brisk Canada day, and the mustard just totally made the sandwich. Speaking from a New Yorker who has Katz at her disposal, I think this was a great sandwich and a must-try.

I mean, really, what can I say about Canada's best and most renowned deli that hasn't been said by 2,500 Yelpers? It's awesome. Very awesome. First, expect a jam-packed restaurant and a line. We came at 9 pm on a Tuesday ... still a line!Second: Get EVERYTHING! The Cole Slaw is crisp and perfectly vinegary. The pickle is the biggest, juiciest one I've had outside NYC (cut it ... eating by hand will invariably lead to a river of pickle juice down your sleeve). The fries are crisp and so good condiments are superfluous.Smoked meat is a must! Three options: lean, medium, and fatty. I had medium, my wife had fatty ... both were amazing. She had hers as part of a combo plate with a lean, perfect steak, with Schwartz's rightfully famous blend. I had mine as a sandwich, stuffed high with a perfect amount of mustard.We came, we saw, we ate ... and it was amazing.

There is no smoked meat quite like Schwartz's. What they say is true. The downside is you are paying tourist prices for tourist quantities. The locals clearly keep coming for that quality but it's tough to justify $11 for a tiny sandwich and $9 for a moderately sized poutine with not quite enough curds. On the other hand, $10 for the poutine à la Schwartz comes smothered in smoked meat and is a much better but. If I return, I would probably buy a pound of meat and maker my own sandwiches for cheaper. Very strong 4 stars for now.Pro tip: Pickles are all natural. Pick a pickle if you choose.

What can I say about a Montreal classic ? Lots of great things everyone knows that if you craving smoked meat and can brave standing in line for an hour Schwartz is the go to place to get that mountain of smoked brisket piled on rye bread with the little bit of mustard. And of course that's exactly what I had and loved every bite of it. I think it's also good to know that you can always get sliced warm or cold mountains of beef to go or vacuum packaged pieces of brisket as well so no matter what you can always bring home some extra when you know you'll be craving more once your done eating

Very very popular tourist deli in Montreal. I am not sure if it is really the best but it does have a good atmosphere of a local family own deli. Fresh cut meat with fresh bread are delicious yet simple. They have turkey sandwich too if you want it but no one ate that

This place has a really good sandwich.   We got there on a Monday afternoon and the line was out the door.  We found out that there was another door that allowed you to order to go food, so we opted for that.   I order the corned beef sandwich with a pickle.   We were able to sit at the bar stools and enjoy the food.

Disclaimer: you have to read this review considering the fact that you need to wait 1 hour to get in.If you have tried katz delicatessen in NYC and loved it, you will love schwartz too! "Smoked meat" sandwich is as good as a perfect pastrami or brisket sandwich at Katz. The meat is lean yet very juicy and super tender and delicious. They serve absolutely nothing with the sandwiches and you should order sides if you want anything with them. So that's a down point. Also, no matter when you visit, you probably end up waiting in a line outside for 1 hour so be mindful of that. To me it's totally worth it though. I would also recommend trying the slaw and the pickles.

A must do if you are a fan of smoked meat and are in Montreal. We showed up for lunch on a Friday and the line was down the street to the corner of the building. A little discouraging at first but it wasn't really that bad since these people were experts at getting people in and out. The place was old and pretty small and we felt a little cramped having to share a table with other people but they turned out to be very friendly. The employees seemed all business but we're actually pretty friendly as well.As for the sandwich, it was delicious. All you have to do is order a smoked meat sandwich and specify your preferred level of fat (lean, medium or fatty). Otherwise it only comes one way (smoked meat on white bread with yellow mustard). Simple but delicious.

We obviously had to come here and it lived up to the hype. The smoked meat was so delicious. The coleslaw was different in that it didn't have mayo but it was so good. The poutine and pickle were also great. Would highly recommend, just know they are cash only

Been in Montreal 3 years now, only now have I been able to take time out to go here. Went here the day everything opened after the lockdown. So luckily, no line. We sat and ordered the latge smoked meat. The bread they give does not complement the meat. So I suggest if you get takeout, use better bread. We ended up not being able to finish, so packed up half the meat, it tasted wayy better with brown grainy toasted bread. The meat, however, that's what they are famous for, was really good. I recommend, definitely.

Typical Jewish deli type restaurant which is some a dozen in New York City. Being from New York, gives me a good base for comparison. You certainly don't come to a place like this for service. Although in NYC, service isn't too bad. First impressions, as we walked in a nice girl told us we can sit anywhere we'd like. Once further in, a man, who seemed to be working there forever, maybe a boss, told us rudely barked at us to sit down and the way we had to sit. We couldn't sit next to each other. Wouldn't recommend talking to him. (Picture of him enclosed.)Food... Well it wasnt terrible. But it was certainly nothing to write home about. This smoked meet is basically somewhere between a Pastrami and Corned beef. Taste-wise, it was a bit bland. Texture was crumbly at best. The meat just didn't hold together too well. It's important for the meat to be Tender and at least hold it's shape. Tender it wasn't, it was just more dry than anything. The amount of mustard on it was skimpy. We also ordered a pickle. It a sour pickle, was pretty good. No other option of pickles. I guess I'm too used to NYC where we can easily get at least 3 different options. I prefer a "new pickle" with my smoked meat sandwich. Coleslaw in the fridge looked old and yellow, so decided not to get that.In short, my humble opinion is, any random Jewish deli place in New York will blow this place out of the water easily. It'll be like a Lambo racing a Camry.Come to experience this place if you'd like. May the Schwartz be with you...... =/

Friends both in Montréal and around the US told me that if I wanted smoked meat, Schwartz's was the place to go. And Schwartz's did not disappoint. I showed up around 5 PM on a Thursday evening, hoping to beat the dinner rush. While the place was quite busy, there was not yet a line out the door and being alone meant that I could snag a seat at the counter immediately. Surprisingly, I was greeted in English both at the door and by the person taking my order. Don't tell the OQLF!For my meal, I ordered the classic: the small smoked meat plate,medium, with a black cherry to drink. About 5 minutes later, I had at least half a pound of smoked goodness in front of me, along with stack of rye bread. I quickly made it into a sandwich and dug in. And holy crap was it good. The meat melted in my mouth. It was far better than I could have ever imagined. I was still somewhat full from that day's lunch, so I ended up leaving about half of the meat on the plate. Don't worry- I brought that back to the hotel and reheated it for my "dessert" that night. No way in heck was I going to let any meat go to waste."If the meat was so good, why only 4 stars?" you might ask. Well, a couple reasons. For one, it's a tad pricey compared to some of the other regional smoked meat places. You're paying inflated tourist prices. But IMO, it's worth the added cost. The other thing (which grinds my gears a little bit) is that the place is cash only, which there is no mention of until you're at the register with a credit card out to pay (the sign above says "CASH" with a US exchange rate, but not "cash only").Sure, there are other smoked meat places in Montréal. But if you want the best, go to Schwartz's. You might have to wait, but it's worth the wait. Just remember to bring cash to pay the bill.
An old Jewish gem in Montreal! The meat was super tender and had an amazing taste. Goes perfect with the pickle and cherry coke

Amazing smoked meat sandwich - much worth it to order the largest platter and share it among friends (there is a $2 fee for sharing) but I think it's still bang for buck.They also serve you bread as well if you order the large platter so no need to get additional bread. Place is small and generally there is a 15 minute wait to get in. You dine in and dine out as it's not really a place to stay for obvious reasons being crammed and too busy.Highly recommend in general and if you're in the area to definitely give it a try!

I may have a lot of haters for saying this but it was meh to me.My boyfriend and I came by to grab some meats to go. I went in line as he walked up to the front and noticed the dine in line had a wait while the take-out line didn't.We went into the take out section (low key: there are seating area in the take-out section too, limited though).I ordered a pound of smoked meats for a friend while he ordered a pound of smoked meats and a season spice package. There was a slight disorganization behind the counter, since my boyfriend was waiting for some time before they realized they didn't proceed with his order.My boyfriend devoured the meats while I was expecting it to melt in your mouth bursting in flavours.
Sweet sweet meat. There's always a line for dine in so consider take out!Definitely get the smoked meat sandwich! The meat is so fatty yet sweet. We also enjoyed the poutine a la Schwartz.

Doesn't look like much when you pass by, but the place is  a well-oiled machine inside getting customers in and out with efficiency. The restaurant always has long lines so be prepared to be waiting a while during peak hours. Also annoying is that they don't accept credit but they do have an ATM. The smoked meat is of course what they're known for and should definitely be the first item you try here. For those that can't eat a lot, a smoked meat sandwich is enough. The smoked meat plate is about 1.5-2x the amount of meat and bread. The smoked meat is great here and definitely a must try in Montreal.

A bunch of the reviews that I've read compare it to Katz in New York. I would have to agree with them. Katz is perhaps better than Schwartz but for half the price, you can enjoy Schwartz north of the border. Schwartz definitely carry's their own wait and serves a very high quality smoked meat sandwich. I waited in line for a good 30 minutes. It actually didn't feel long, and even got to skip a few people since I was by myself and was fortunate enough to get a seat at the bar. I ordered their Smoked Meat Sandwich and received a sandwich within literally 10 seconds. I also ordered a side of fries that were very tasty. The smoked meat was perfectly placed in between to slices of rye bread with some mustard. The meat was very tender and not fatty at all. The perfectly seasoned meat was so addicting I kept taking bites and eventually ran out of bites. The fries were golden, crispy perfectly fried and tasted fresh. Schwartz definitely lives up to their hype and I hope I One day return to Montreal to get to experience this all over again.

When researching restaurants in the Montreal area schawrtz's was always on the list so I knew we needed to make a stop. My expectations were met! The smoked meat sandwich was perfect, it had the perfect ratio of lean meat and fatty pieces. The poutine wasn't prefect but the gravy was really good. I only wish I lived in the area for more visits.

Being very familiar with NYC, I love a good pastrami sandwich. But when in Montréal, it's called Smoked Meat.We arrived around noon on a Sunday and the line was manageable, about a 15 minute wait. As you walk in, it's no frills, just how I like it. Tightly seated space that runs efficiently. We all got the smoked meat sandwich with pickles and an order of poutine. The smoked meat sandwich was very good. It's a bit leaner and stringier than pastrami but it makes sense because usually smoked meat is made from a brisket cut, as opposed to pastrami which is from the fattier navel. Despite being less fatty, the smoked meat was still tender and tasty. Poutine was solid.FYI- it's cash only! You can actually pay with USD but they will charge 10% additional.

Line could be long outside, but be patient, you won't regret it! Took my friends from NYC to Schwartz's and they were amazed with how good the meat is; the flavor and texture are just unbelievable. As I'm writing this, already planning my next trip to the plateau to get some more smoked meat :)Tips: if you are in a big group, order plates of just smoked meat then make the sandwiches yourself, save on money and get more meat!

I ordered the combo for two with spicy fries and it did not disappoint. Montreal style smoked meat is very good and i they propose lean, medium with a bit of fat or with more fat. I took the medium as the fat gives it a bit of flavor. Though, portion are big and took us two days to finish. Enjoy:)

Was it good? ABSOLUTELY!!!  The whole experience was just amazing. The wait outside in the cold (worth it). It felt like I opened the door and went straight to 1929. What an experience. We were a group of six so it took a bit to get in and get settled. The menu is so simple, it was almost confusing, and I was terrified it would be like a Seinfeld 'soup nazi' episode if I messed up. BUT nothing could've been further from the truth, even though there weren't too many smiles, they were sweethearts, and very helpful!!When I started ordering the waiter basically told me to slow my roll, I was ordering a lot of food.  Most joints would want you to order as much as they could sell you, but this guy helped us get the order right and he said 'if you're still hungry, we can always order more'. Now I think, no I'm sure, this guy was shocked at the amount of food I put away, he said I might have to put your picture on the wall. On to the food. I had been told by my cousin in Vancouver that Montreal Smoked meat is 10x better than Pastrami, he's got it twisted, in my world of food the ranking goes 1) Caviar, 2) Foie Gras, and 3) Pastrami- in that order, and everything else, well it doesn't really matter. Schwartz's ranks between Pastrami and Corned-beef. It's DAMN GOOD. I have had better Pastrami, but this hangs with the best. The slaw was fantastic, get it!!!!  The dill pickles were amazing and so were the fries. Got the black cherry cola, very good. We also got the rib-eye for my daughter and the chicken for my other daughter. All were outstanding. Don't let the haters discourage you, this place is worth the hype and a must on your visit to Montreal. Schwartz's you did not disappoint. Merci mon frier

This is the place if you want a massive stack of smoked meat between two slices of bread. It's delicious although I would still opt for Katz's Deli in New York. That said, still an excellent sandwich. Poutine was average. The chips were perfect but the brown sauce was bland and the cheese too melty.

Everyone is crazy about the smoke beef sandwich here. I went there during lunch time and saw a long line outside. There are a waiting line for dine in. I am a tourist but I am not that crazy to wait for it especially I am hungry. Then I found out there is a to go on the left side of the restaurant. There were still a long line but it move fast since everyone just grab the sandwich and go. I got it and it was pretty small compare to the picture on yelp. It was alright with two thinly slice bread and lot of meats, some were a bit salty. Some were dry and some were tender, it was really inconsistent. The flavor was great without a question. You can also purchase the package to go from their refrigerator. Overall it was average, maybe it might be different if I dine in but I never will want to wait in that long line just for a sandwich.

I went there when one of my friends were visiting from the SF Bay Area and wanted to try Montreal smoked meat! So, we went there during summer time and waited outside for maybe half-an-hour even for the takeout. I had already tried smoked meat in different places even though it was my first time at the Schwartz. The sandwich was good, I must give that, but I don't think it's worth 30 min waiting in a long run in a hot summer.

A must-go in Montreal, the smoked meat poutine was piled high with the meat (and subsequently smushed down with a lid), and was guiltily satisfying in all of its meaty, gravy, squeaky cheese goodness. Given that it had just snowed several feet during our visit and not too many folks were out, we barely had a wait and sat in the back enjoying more than our fair share of meat. Would come back in a heartbeat, I can remember the taste of the poutine as I write this review.

Still great as always.  Tastes the same throughout the years and service is quick.  Tried the hot peppers for the first time today and I would recommend that as a nice palette cleanser to accompany your sandwich.

I used to live right by Schwartz's so I always walked passed the never ending queue of people lining up for them. Doesn't matter what time of the day it is, it's always busy. They've been around since 1928 (celebrating their 90th anniversary)!We dropped in on a Monday evening (around 9:00pm). No line but it was busy inside. We grabbed a table in the back and put in our orders right away. The menu is up on the walls: sandwiches (smoked meat, turkey and salami), side orders and larger plates. Simple and small.- Dill pickle ($2.35) - we got one pickle to share. Good crunchy texture. - 2x Smoked meat sandwich ($9.95) - you choose what type of meat you want (lean, medium and fatty). We both went with medium as you get the best of both worlds. They pile up the smoked meat along with mustard slathered on the bread. Satisfying. It's still as good as my last visit. Reliable, reasonably priced and an iconic institution in Montreal.

So we were waiting to try the smoked meat sandwich from the time we got to Montreal, in fact, I had this place on my list of places to try out since the time we decided to move to montreal. So the bread size does make u think this sandwich is a small one but the way they load the meat up is crazy. And they put a fatty strip towards the end of the sandwich so u don't find the sandwich too dry. I thought I would miss an au jous with it but I didnt. it had the perfect amount of mustard and tasted really good. On talking with the staff, I found that they take Christmas orders for roasting the whole duck and turkey for u. all u gotta do is place your order a week before Christmas! The place doesn't seem fancy but it's got a great smoked meat sandwich for sure!

$17.88 for a black cherry soda, pickle and a smoked meat sandwich. A little pricey for what it is...I came here on a Sunday with a friend. After a 10 minute wait, we were seated inside which isn't unusual for such a known place. As previously stated, I got the smoked meat sandwich with a pickle and soda. The smoked meat was really good. Very tasty, with lots of flavour. It was however somewhat greasy. But, it is expected on such a fatty sandwich. As for the rye, it seemed to fall apart after taking a couple bites out of it. Possibly due to the grease or mustard. The rye was really good and fresh tasting though. The pickle was really good too. It was sour and crunchy, and quite large. However, I was expecting the sandwich to come with one included. I was hesitant to get a pickle due to the price (close to $3 for a single pickle), but for a smoked meat sandwich, it's a must. As for the soft drink, my only comment is that the price point is quite high for such a cheap one. I remember it used to be sold at the dollar store for $0.33 cents per can... (priced at close to $3). Overall, I would recommend this restaurant to anyone. It is very delicious and quite filling. However, at it's current price point, I would advise going once in a while.

Best smoked meat in town. Very simple menu but high quality stuff. Try the smoked meat in a sandwich with rye, mustard, and a pickle. The lines can get long, an alternative is stopping by in the evening and grabbing fresh meat (don't buy the frozen one it makes no sense) and then consume this at home, it is delish.
Not sure what all the noise is about this place. It was filthy inside and totally unsanitary. Gross is a more accurate word. I guess the grease kills the germs...

30 mins wait on a holiday weekend afternoon for a tiny (shorter than my palm tiny) $12 smoked meat sandwich, I didn't feel was worth it. Quality of the meat was great but could use more flavor. Got their regular (mix of lean and fatty meat) for takeout.

Schwartz's is a smoked meat deli in Montreal. They are famous for their hot smoked meat sandwich and smoked meat by the pound, which has been compared to pastrami in NY.There were two lines for Schwartz's. One for take out and one for sit in to dine. We opted for the take out, since that line was much shorter (and involved an indoor wait).We ordered 1.5 pounds of the smoked meat and one smoked meat sandwich. The hot smoked meat sandwich was good. The pastrami was crumbly, slightly juicy, somewhat fatty, had some mustard and in between two slices of white bread. The pastrami was definitely drier than Katz or Pastrami Queen in NY. The box of smoked meat was not so great. There were slices of smoked meat congealed in the box. It tasted like smoked corned beef, it was sinewy and chewy and not melt in your mouth. I would return to give them another try!

Probably the number one place I wanted to try in Montreal and it did not disappoint. Came here by myself and the line to get in was huge and out the door to the corner. Luckily by me being by myself, I was jumped all the way ahead to one seat at the counter. For my food I had the go to and that is the Montreal smoked meat sandwich. The sandwich isn't big but taste excellent, great, and every other wonderful thing to say. The cut of the meat reminds  me of a bread basket sandwich back home in the metro Detroit area. Just perfect is the sandwich. Along with the sandwich, I had some of their poutine. It's was ok, nothing special to me. I believe it's cash only and it's just a great old throwback deli. Another must have if you come to Montreal.
The best deli sandwich I've ever had. They put mustard on the sandwich which adds perfect flavour to it. Have one at the park nearby.

I've been to Montreal many times but I've never eaten at this place until this past weekend.  My expectations were high due to many ppl raving about it non-stop.  I'm happy to say that the hype is real with this one.  My wife and I were worried that there would be a long lineup but to our surprise, there wasn't one when we arrived.  We just walked in and immediately got a table.  The decor of this place had a "retro" vibe to it and on the walls were faces of the famous celebs who have visited this place.  You could tell there is a great deal of history that is attached to this restaurant.We each ordered their famous smoked meat sandwich with medium fat with a side order of pickle , a poutine, an extra order of bread, and 2 black cherry sodas.  The food came very fast and before we know it, we were sinking our teeth into this massive mountain of smoke meat in between these 2 pieces of bread and boy was it heavenly!  I love mustard so I drenched mine with it.  Their poutine was excellent as well, something about their gravy.Overall, the service was friendly and the food lived up to the hype.  What more can you ask for? Not sure when we will be back in Montreal but it's definitely a place to eat when you are in town!  I highly recommend it!

The star of the show here is the spiced and brined beef brisket, hot-smoked and steamed, yielding something similar to corned beef or pastrami but taking it a step further. Jews from Eastern European introduced the smoked meat sandwich to Montreal nearly a century ago, and one of the main vendors of this specialty is the legendary Schwartz's Deli.A smoked meat sandwich comes piled high with slices of hand-cut meat served on fresh rye bread with yellow mustard. Unlike pastrami which uses leaner parts of the brisket, smoked meat includes the fatty parts of the muscle. You can specify your cut when ordering as lean, medium, or fatty. Faced with this question recent visions of foie gras and poutine danced in my head. This was no time to start showing restraint in a city that shows no restraint, gastronomically speaking. Fatty it was! As expected the meat was tender and juicy and complemented by the grainy spice of the yellow mustard slathered to both sides of the bread. The flavor of the meat was new and different to me, no surprise when you consider the week-long curing process it undergoes in a blend of whole peppercorns, coriander, mustard seed, and garlic, among other secret ingredients. Sides to enjoy with this meaty goodness include frites maison (house fries), cornichon (pickle), and salade de choux (coleslaw). The coleslaw was greener and tangier than traditional American coleslaw, being dressed with vinegar instead of globs of mayonnaise. The fries were thick and generously salted but there were definitely inconsistencies in the texture, with some of the fries being overly soggy and limp.Almost as famous as Schwartz's smoked meat is the perpetual line out the door, which we were fortunate enough to avoid. Eating dinner at senior citizen times can have its benefits. The ten minutes we did spend waiting outside were a chance to point and laugh at people who can't park. Inside the experience felt like a visit to Nate 'n Al except you're packed like sardines at family-style picnic tables and you're nowhere near Beverly Hills. Counter seating is also available where you can witness the meat-cutting process in all its juicy, savory glory.By the time you leave, you and your clothes are thoroughly scented of meat. It's an aroma--and a taste--that I quite enjoyed for what was ultimately a sophisticated and time-honored technique delivered in simplistic and humble sandwich form. Schwartz's Deli is a can't-miss in Montreal, especially for a first-timer. Just prepare yourself for what will likely be a long wait and getting to know your neighbors quite well while you eat.

So Schwartz's has over 2000 reviews on Yelp at the time that I'm writing this review and over 2000 photos.  It's a Montreal Institution.  It does not need my patronage nor my endorsement, so I will try to just include useful tips in this review and try to make it at least entertaining to read.If you go before 10am, there will be no lineups, but you cannot get a hot smoked meat sandwich.  The meat will be cold.  I recommend waiting until after 10am and getting it hot.If you arrive between 10am-10:30am there will likely be no line up or the lineup will be fairly short.There are 2 doors, one for takeout and one for dine-in.  The takeout line is almost always shorter than the dine-in line, the choice is yours.It's $10.45 for a smoked meat sandwich on rye with mustard.  There are no other toppings.  The default is medium fattiness.  You can request lean or fat.  They give you a lot of meat, but I still personally find the price expensive for just a sandwich.Decor is reminiscent of those old time delis in NYC.The very first time I tried Schwartz's was many moons ago when I was actually living in Montreal.  I have never been a fan of smoked meat, having had it at chains like Shopsy's and Druxy's, and even at the now defunct, but at the time very famous Ben's on de Maisonneuve (in Montreal).  I was reluctant to line up and try Schwartz's, but my dining companion insisted that I give it a try.  We ended up getting a smoked meat sandwich each, fries and a cherry soda.  After taking my first bite into my first Schwartz's smoked meat sandwich, I finally understood why people liked smoked meat.  It's like I was eating cooked deli ham my whole life and said I hated ham, and then one day I had some bone-in smoked ham, like the ones served at Easter, and then I finally understood the appeal of ham.  Prior to Schwartz's I thought all smoked meat was somewhat slimy and meh, but the smoked meat at Schwartz's is not slimy at all and more fibrous, if that make any sense.  The way bone-in smoked ham is more fibrous than cooked deli ham.  The fries were unmemorable and the cherry soda was a can of Cott's Black Cherry soda.  I remember service being surly, and the place was packed and very warm.  Although I liked the smoked meat, I did not return again until very recently (over a decade since my first visit), and only because my mom really wanted to try it.We got take out.  We arrived at 9:45am and there was absolutely no lineup and that is when we learned that before 10am the meat is served cold.  We said we would return after 10am.  We walked around and returned at 10:10am.  The guy at the takeout counter said that his meat was not ready yet (lol) so he sent us next door to the dine-in restaurant for takeout.  The restaurant was about 80% full at that time, and there was 1 person ahead of us also ordering takeout.  It was less than 10 minutes from the time we ordered to the time we paid and left.The meat was as I remembered it.  The bread wasn't that fresh this time though.  My mom thought the sandwich was good, but she said she would not want to eat there again on her next trip to Montreal.  However, she is happy that she tried it.Maybe my third visit will be sometime in the 2030's.  LOL.

The famous Schwartz's!!! It was very very good. Great experience. We went mid morning/noon so we definitely beat the rush/long line up.It really is a must try when you come to Montreal. Everyone including other customers were super friendly and an overall great vibe in that place.I'd definitely go back to try out their other meals.Cash or debit only just an FYI.

This place really grinds my gears. It's such a touristy spot yet a must get if you're visiting from out of town. The hype can and will deliver. If you tell me Kat'z in NYC is better I will let you run your own face into my open palm hand. There's no mistake, they do meat so righteously so, I will forever compare any brisket to this standard, I'm indefinitely ruined. I was lucky enough to not have a wait, which probably added to the amazing experience I encountered, but would I wait in line for this? absolutely. There's no point in going into detail about what has been said already by the masses, this place has all the rave it needs and deservingly so. Meaty perfection is just an agonizing wait away, but worth it. It's a oral sensation that you never want to end, so do yourself a favor and order more than you expect to eat so you have some for later. Trust. Stay fat mother suckers

Summary: delicious and well seasoned smoked meat! Sandwiches priced at $12+ CAD. Take out or dine in available. A must try while in Montreal!My husband and I visited on a Thursday afternoon and the place was packed. We ended up ordering a sandwich to go just to try because of all the great things we've heard. You ordered first and then paid while your order was being prepared. This was my first smoked meat sandwich and it was delicious! I definitely had that "first bite" euphoric experience! Highly recommend!

Tips:The line can get really long and the line doesn't move very fast in my opinion. If you come on a weekend or during a peak eating hour, don't come extremely hungry.You can ask for leaner meat or fattier meet in your smoked meat sandwiches ------------------------------------------------------------------The smoked meats are absolutely delicious. I would definitely come again and wait in that line for these smoked meats. I would recommend the sandwich, it seems like the most representative of what Schwartz has to offer. They don't skimp on the meat and you get to try their great tasting mustard. I'm not usually a fan of mustard, but It went perfect with the smoked meats.

If it's good enough for the celebs I'm in! This iconic smoke meat joint has always been my go to for myself or for friends that come to visit Montreal. This place is no games, get your sandwich in a small cafeteria like setting, sit down on a shared table and make  conversations with the people rubbing your shoulders as you eat. This place is packed! I always get the same thing. Smoke meat sandwich with medium fat. Oh man that fat glistening in the juices of the meat, Dayummmm good! Just make sure you eat the sandwich on its side like a hotdog to keep the meat from not leaving the sandwich. It's a technique I've mastered over the years. Schwartz Deli gives you what you need. No more less.

Oh my goodness. Here on a ladycation and I got some suggestions from some fellow Yelpers to come here. Smoked meat sandwiches were on the menu and this place was a must try. We got here and it was a hole in the wall. Just what you would expect to see for a diner that has been around since the 20s. We stood in line and waited for our table. The staff was quick and friendly.Our waiter told us the best sellers and we ordered right away. Nothing fancy just a sandwich. Now me being the cheapo that I am was wondering if a $9 sandwich would be worth it. And it was. I shouldn't have doubted it.It came fast and I devoured it. The meat was tender and juicy, smoked perfectly. It was everything you would want in a sandwich. Simple and to the point. Don't expect anything over the top if you come here. Simple and to the point. But totally worth it.

For me, the issue was consistency. I had Schwartz's (main dining area) my first night in Montreal. Really nice staff and the sandwich was bomb! The bread was soft and smoked meat was juicy. It was so good, I told my wife we had to come back before we leave Montreal. The night before our flight, we went back to Schwartz (takeout side). Totally different experience. The staff wasn't as nice and the sandwich was dry. Bread was not so soft and smoked meat wasn't as juicy. I was disappointed. I should've not gone back and left my first experience as the only experience on our trip.

Underwhelmed and disappointed, I had really high expectations for their smoked meat. Everyone talked this place up like It was going to blow my mind. We didn't bother dining in, there was a line, It was snowing. I just wanted a taste. We went next door to their "to go" side, they also had some bar stools in the back to sit. I shared a sandwich and poutine with my husband. The bread is just a simple slice of bread with a little bit of mustard. The mustard did help cut the Fattiness of the meat. We had some pretty nice cuts, not too much fat but It is very heavy. Flavor was okay, I expected more. I would prefer pastrami over smoked meat. There was just nothing special about It. I was craving poutine, and was also disappointed. Both the gravy and fries were bland. The cheese curds were nice though. Way too overhyped but I understand the novelty of It. I mean It was enough for me to come in and give It a try I guess lol. Overall it's one of those places to try, just so you can say you did. I wouldn't consider It a regular go to though.

My first time trying smoked meat!  Everyone said this was a must try when visiting Montreal, and I definitely see why. For those of us coming from the states, the meat has a slightly different taste from pastrami, but it is quite similar. The sandwich has a good smoky taste but it is on the smaller side. One tip, they have both a sit down restaurant, as well as a take-out section with tables in the back. Because there's often a long line, I'd recommend the take out option as opposed to waiting for a table. This was a great option for me since I visited by myself.

In my opinion this spot is better than Katz Delicatessen in NYC. A MUST if you're visiting Montreal. By the appearance I thought it would be too overwhelming to eat due to the amount of meat. But after one bite, I wanted two sandwiches! The meat is so lean yet fatty, so flavorful yet plain. The meat melts in your mouth as you chew it, and the mustard adds a very necessary touch.The place is fairly packed though, and the service isn't that great (which is the case in most very high traffic restaurants of this kind). You pay in the front after you eat and if you're from out of town they definitely try to get a bigger tip out of you.

So I went back again. And this time I went into the dine in as opposed to the take out section. The sandwich was much better this time and they used a different kind of bread. Also not as dry as the previous one I had from the take out section.They do, however take cash only. There is an atm in the shopper's next door which has a desjardin atm. The service is great as always.

Okay, I'm not a huge red meat person, but this smoked meat was indeed delicious. However, not sure if it was worth the wait and it was clear that a lot of the attention was on the meat and not much on anything else. Not that clean, which I guess is supposed to preserve character, but the bread with the meat was also just so subpar. Subpar enough that I didn't understand why they wouldn't upgrade a little more. You also are squeezed in to sit with other tables. I just think a little bit of a makeover and attention to detail couldn't hurt the preservation of the history.

The Schwartz's sandwich is undeniably amazing!  The meat is so tender, juicy and flavorful.  The mustard and bread are compliments, but there's no question the meat is the star of the show.  Hands down one of the best sandwiches you'll ever eat.  Go mid week or early in the day to avoid the lines.  My only complaint comes after watching the staff interact with customers, they were rude.  I suggest grabbing the sandwich to go so you don't have to sit at the picnic style tables but don't wait long to eat the sandwich, it's best warm!

You got smoked meat, bro?For perfectly smoked and steamed smoke meat (think French-Canadian pastrami), you gotta hit Schwartz's.The service is on point. The sides are on point. The meat is on point (brisket pun for those in the know). They have what you need, if what you need is perfectly seasoned and smoked beef with mustard on rye.Bring cash, get meat, leave happy. There's nothing else to say.

Simplicity redefined, it's your average neighbourhood deli but it is not when it comes to your experience. Whether you are on the go or need a proper meal to eat and don't mind the crowd or waiting outside to get a place to sit, for sure you are heading for a gem, the food, the service, the ambience and the prices are great and no matter you are in doubt or know exactly what you want you will be pleased from the outcome. Schwartz's is a real place for real people.

We stopped by here for the famous, iconic Montreal smoked meat sandwich. I love the ambiance and decor in this tiny shop. I love the framed newspaper articles and various awards Schwartz's has earned over the years. We decided to order takeout because the dine in line was way too long. My now-husband dropped me off so I could get in line while he parked the car a little bit away. The menu is very basic and small; there are not many food options here. From my husband's perspective (since I don't eat meat): the sandwich was very tasty and the meat was fresh. However, the rye bread was too small. Overall, this was a smaller sandwich than we expected (even based on having previously seen the pictures on Yelp). The cost is perhaps a little bit high for what it is, but it was a memorable sandwich.There are so many outstanding food choices in Montreal that we probably would not come back here, but we're so glad we went once for the experience.

You have to stop in, right? This Jewish Deli is a mainstay in Montreal. They've been serving up their smoked seasoned meats for decades. Celine Dion even bought the place a while back to keep it going (so we heard). The #4 is what you want if you're a first timer. It's served on rye with mustard. It's not really pastrami and it's not really corned beef - it's more like the latter but fattier. You have to add a pickle and some of their incredible cole slaw and wash it all down with a cold Coke! Nirvana!!!Loved the counter waiters too! True classic deli counter. Glad we tried it.

It's inevitable that when you come to Montreal, smoked meat is brought up and both times I've visited, I came to Schwartz. Many people say that others have taking over the reign for the best smoke meat sandwiches but I beg to differ. Opened since 1928, once you try them you'll see why I recommend them. There's a reason why there have roughly 10,000 reviews on Google and 2,500 on Yelp. I highly recommend checking them out at least once while you are in Montreal!

Quality is definitely better when you dine!The first time I came, the meat was juicy, flavourful and rich. Waited 6 years to make the trip back to Montreal to have this sandwich! Quite different the second time around:Meat was dry and crumbly (note, that I did choose lean instead of medium), but it just wasn't as juicy as the first time. Also, the bread was squished cuz we did the take out (the line ups were ridiculously long!) There were still sit in seats for take out at the back. Overall, dine in for juicier meats with better presentation!

I felt like this place was a bit over-hyped. The ambiance gives off a nice old diner vibe which was kind of nice for this type of food. The photos of the food were appetizing and palpable, but didn't live up to the look. The waitress was nice and quick with very high turnover. This place definitely serves better quality smoke meat than most places but I honestly think it might not be worth the wait.

Excellent food, atmosphere and service.  This is an institution in Montreal and it does not disappoint.  The smoked meat, slaw, atmosphere and service are the stars for sure.Just be prepared for a few things.  It's crazy packed and hectic during lunch and dinner (I suggest going during slower times).  It's full of tourists who add to the confusion.  You share tables with strangers.  It's cash only.  Many locals hate on it, because it's so popular with tourists (kind of like the cool kids hating on something after it becomes mainstream).

From what I gather this place is an institution, so when we walked by it and there was no line-up, we had to go and check it out (despite literally just having a bite to eat less than an hour before - all for the love of good food). Definitely got that diner vibe where anyone can take an empty seat and get a chance to mingle with complete strangers - loved it! They also pretty much kick you out when you're done especially when the line ups start going. We didn't get kicked out but the couple beside us were pretty much told they should go, even though they were still drinking their coffee post-meal.We told our server that it was our first time here and wasn't sure what to get exactly and he didn't seem to really care. We ended up getting the smoked brisket, liver steak, coleslaw and fries.Liver steak - just straight up liver with not much else, served medium-rare. No real flavour and was a bit tough. Wasn't a huge fan considering I love anything liver.Slaw and fries were pretty solid and were great sides. Slaw was vinegar-based and perfectly contrasted the fatty smoked brisket we got.There were 3 different choices for the brisket (lean, medium, fatty). We specifically told the guy it was our first time here and when we ordered fatty, we thought that the brisket would have that rim of fat on the edges. But when got it, it was literally fat everywhere. It really would've been nice to have gotten a heads up. When he saw that we barely ate anything, he was like, "maybe I should've told you how fatty it was"... A little too late dude!

We all know the history of this historical restaurant. A meal for under 20 dollars includes, a smoked meat(medium) sandwich, fries, and a soda pop. If you go there often,  you better be burning all those calories and fat that you're taken in, if not, you'll be in  health trouble down the line.

One of the main things I wanted to try while in Montreal was the infamous Montreal smoked meat sandwiches. Schwartz is quite well reviewed and so I was really looking forward to trying it.I came during lunch time and the line up wasn't too long. It was quite a scorching hot day in August and I was glad that the line up moved relatively quickly. I was really happy that the air conditioning was so strong inside. I was seated on the counter with a great view of the smoked meat getting cooked.I ordered the regular smoked meat sandwich and it was massive. It had 10-15 thin layers of meat between two pieces of whole grain bread. The meat was so moist and flavourful, you could see the peppercorns but it wasn't spicy at all. I'm glad they gave me a fork because I really did need it to eat all the meat that spilled out. This was so good. My only gripe with the sandwich was the bread - it was just very plain bread that didn't add much to the sandwich. I think it would be great with a more high quality bread instead.I would definitely back next time. It's a great meal and it totally deserves the high rating.

WOOOOW. I googled before visiting Montreal what to eat and smoked meat is the Montreal food. I came here to try it. It is very tasty! The smoked meat is delicious. Sandwich contains so much meat and very filling. The line is short and I got take-out. English works.

It's not hard to see why the line for Schwartz's is almost always out the door. You will literally see the line before you see the storefront. For all the newcomers out there though, don't be intimidated!The line moves very quickly! My pro tip: get in the takeout line. There's a tiny counter at the back of this section of the restaurant where you can take your food. Alternatively, you can take your food down a couple blocks to reach the green where there are benches aplenty at the base of Mont Royal! The smoked meat is the one thing you need to get here at Schwartz's!! Whether in the form of a sandwich or on top of your poutine (Poutine a la Schwartz's), the smoked meat is to die for. It's slow-cooked and falls apart when prodded ever so gently with a fork. The meats aren't necessarily smoky, but they are very well-seasoned. If you haven't yet been, take my word for it. I assure you there exist fewer simple joys in life than a mass of smoked meat sandwiched between two slices of rye bread and slathered with mustard.
